dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The Shanghai INE futures market is actually outpacing the volume of Brent and WTI contracts, which is pretty surprising.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Shanghai I N E futures market is actually outpacing the volume of Brent and W T I contracts, which is pretty surprising.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Of course the volume of trades on the Shanghai INE still lags behind that of the Brent oil contracts traded in London and the West Texas Intermediate oil futures traded in New York.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but it's interesting that despite that high volume, multinational traders are mostly ignoring it—except for Glencore, of course.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but it's interesting that despite that high volume, multinational traders are mostly ignoring it-except for Glencore, of course.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese oil futures contract is, however, being taken seriously by multinational commodity traders (like Glencore) and is priced in a manner that is comparable to the Brent and WTI indices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the pricing mechanism is totally different from Brent and WTI, which has had some real consequences.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the pricing mechanism is totally different from Brent and W T I, which has had some real consequences.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese oil futures contract is, however, being taken seriously by multinational commodity traders (like Glencore) and is priced in a manner that is comparable to the Brent and WTI indices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, like the dip in the renminbi's role in global commodity markets, as The Financial Times pointed out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh, like the dip in the renminbi's role in global commodity markets, as The Financial Times pointed out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As we argue in The Asia-Pacific Journal, these results suggest that Chinas oil futures could bring the renminbi to the core of global commodity markets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And this launch is actually shrinking renminbi-denominated trading instead of expanding it, which seems counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And this launch is actually shrinking renminbi-denominated trading instead of expanding it, which seems counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The launch of the oil futures contract can be anticipated to widen the scope for renminbi-denominated commodity trading.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So foreign suppliers end up with fewer renminbi accounts, and they can't even use them to buy Chinese bonds or securities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So foreign suppliers end up with fewer renminbi accounts, and they can't even use them to buy Chinese bonds or securities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As more of Chinas oil imports come to be priced in its domestic currency, foreign suppliers will have more renminbi-denominated accounts with which they can purchase not only Chinese goods and services, but also Chinese government securities and bonds.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which really hampers the internationalization of the yuan, something China's been pushing for decades.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which really hampers the internationalization of the yuan, something China's been pushing for decades.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This can be anticipated to strengthen Chinese capital markets and promote the renminbis internationalization or at least the progressive de-dollarization of the oil market.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And you know, they've been trying to move away from relying on the IMF's Special Drawing Rights as an alternative reserve currency.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And you know, they've been trying to move away from relying on the I M F's Special Drawing Rights as an alternative reserve currency.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For the past decade, Chinas strategy for internationalizing the renminbi has involved greater reliance on the International Monetary Funds Special Drawing Rights as an alternative international reserve currency.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Li Keqiang, the former PBOC governor, laid out that strategy back in 2011 in an essay, arguing against the SDR.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Li Keqiang, the former P B O C governor, laid out that strategy back in twenty eleven in an essay, arguing against the S D R.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Peoples Bank of Chinas then-governor, Zhou Xiaochuan, spelled out the strategy in an essay in 2009. With new allocations of SDRs to emerging industrial powers like China, the SDR, based on a basket of currencies including the renminbi, could serve not only as a development tool, but also as a means of international payment to rival the US dollar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: He basically said the dollar-centered system was superior, pointing to things like chronic US surpluses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He basically said the dollar-centered system was superior, pointing to things like chronic U S surpluses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Zhous 2009 essay galvanized these efforts, as he pointed to the evident inadequacies of the dollar-centered system (such as the impact of chronic US deficits) and outlined the SDRs advantages as an alternative means of international financial settlement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But now, with US tariffs and sanctions, China's almost embracing dollar dominance rather than challenging it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But now, with U S tariffs and sanctions, China's almost embracing dollar dominance rather than challenging it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The establishment of renminbi-based oil trading at a time when China and many other economies confront aggressive US tariffs, and possible further development of renminbi-based trade in other commodity markets, suggests that the US dollar could face an unprecedented challenge to its hegemony.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's ironic—the Shanghai oil futures contract might actually strengthening the dollar's hegemony, not undermining it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's ironic-the Shanghai oil futures contract might actually strengthening the dollar's hegemony, not undermining it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China no doubt views the emergence of renminbi-denominated oil contracts as a means for Chinese companies to buy oil and gas in their own currency, thereby avoiding exposure to foreign currency fluctuations and firing a shot across the bow of US dollar supremacy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And countries like Russia and Iran won't even accept renminbi for oil payments because of US sanctions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And countries like Russia and Iran won't even accept renminbi for oil payments because of U S sanctions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Both Russia and Iran, for example, are selling oil to China and accepting payment in renminbi, in response to actual or potential sanctions imposed on them by the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So Chinese companies are stuck buying oil in dollars, exposing them to currency risks and boosting dollar supremacy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So Chinese companies are stuck buying oil in dollars, exposing them to currency risks and boosting dollar supremacy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: China no doubt views the emergence of renminbi-denominated oil contracts as a means for Chinese companies to buy oil and gas in their own currency, thereby avoiding exposure to foreign currency fluctuations and firing a shot across the bow of US dollar supremacy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which really weakens China's petroyuan initiatives, even though they're the world's second-largest oil importer.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which really weakens China's petroyuan initiatives, even though they're the world's second-largest oil importer.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The fact that China is now the worlds largest oil importer, as well as its leading trading and manufacturing economy, lends weight to its petroyuan and other initiatives to internationalize the renminbi.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: If they can't withstand US counterattacks, it's gonna be tough to build a multipolar financial world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: If they can't withstand U S counterattacks, it's gonna be tough to build a multipolar financial world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If China can withstand US counterattacks, its efforts will lay the financial groundwork for the emergence of a multipolar world.
